Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Development of Human Technological Abilities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Humans and their ancestors are unique in their ability to alter behavioral strategies in response to changes in the environment and use technology to cope with adaptive problems. The appearance of modified stone tools in the fossil record represents a potential adaptive shift in the human lineage as ancestors accessed nutrient-dense foods, established flexible niches, and began to alter environments through cumulative technology and shape the selective pressures within them. Understanding the origin and transmission of early tool technology is of inherent interest to the evolution of the human lineage. What were the behavioral strategies of early toolmakers? How much energy did toolmakers invest in producing stone artifacts? How did tool behaviors change through evolutionary time? Dr. Tom Plummer and PhD candidate Emma Finestone, of the City University of New York, will conduct a regional study investigating the earliest persistent stone tool industry - termed the Oldowan - across time scales. Oldowan tools vary in size, shape, degree of reduction, and stone raw material type and these properties are thought to reflect behavioral, cognitive, and dietary changes in the human lineage that are often linked to known trends in anatomical and energetic evolution, including an increase in body mass and metabolic rate. This investigation of trends in the Oldowan archaeological record will expand the geographic range of the earliest Oldowan and shed light on the origins of persistent tool use in a broader evolutionary context.

Plummer and Finestone will undertake a project comparing stone tool reduction and raw material procurement at three Oldowan sites spanning nearly a million year interval on the Homa Peninsula in Kenya. This approach offers a snapshot into regional Oldowan behavior and allows researchers to evaluate technological strategies, mobility, and landscape use of some of the earliest toolmakers over time. Using energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence (ED-XRF) geochemical analyses, elemental signatures will link raw materials used in stone tool production to nearby primary outcrops and secondary drainages. This allows researchers to identify raw material sources and determine which sources were utilized by toolmakers and which rock types were most heavily reduced. After identifying regional patterns in stone resource procurement, investigators will reconstruct ranging behavior across the three localities and evaluate if and how investment in stone transport and toolmaker mobility changed through time. This not only addresses the evolution of behavior and archaeology on the Homa Peninsula, but also informs of broader adaptive shifts in the human lineage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Emma Finestone completed research for her dissertation “Oldowan Tool Behaviors through time on the Homa Peninsula, Kenya” supported by the National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award. This project focused on the development of human technological abilities.

The significance of tool use to the human lineage is a central theme in human origins. However, what is known from the early archaeological record suggests that tool use may have begun as an opportunistic behavior with minimal investment, rather than a habitual and widespread adaptive revolution. This project investigated investment in tool production on the Homa Peninsula in southwestern Kenya where three archaeological sites span nearly a million year interval.

During the funding period, Finestone surveyed ancient river beds in southwestern Kenya to locate potential sources of stone raw materials. Samples of stone were analyzed at the University of Nairobi to geochemically link artifacts with their sources. This provided an estimate of where on the landscape human ancestors were accessing materials to make stone tools and how far these ancient toolmakers traveled. The results of this research suggest that toolmakers on the Homa Peninsula preferred durable stone materials and utilized many of the same sources through nearly one million years of evolutionary time. Furthermore, the earliest toolmakers on the Peninsula intentionally transported stones over several kilometers. This level of investment in raw material procurement is greater and more complex than what is previously documented in this time period.

Funding also supported two trips to the National Museum of Kenya in Nairobi, where Finestone collected measurements on the size and shape of Oldowan stone tools from the Homa Peninsula. Her findings suggest that technology on the Homa Peninsula is typical of the Oldowan Industry and the composition of lithic assemblages indicates that tools may have been used for pounding behaviors, in addition to cutting and slicing.

Finestone’s research on the Homa Peninsula, at the National Museums of Kenya, and at the University of Nairobi formed the basis of her dissertation, which was completed in September in 2019. During the funding period, Finestone also traveled to present the this research at academic conferences in Cleveland, Ohio, Albuquerque, New Mexico, and Nairobi, Kenya. The results of this project suggest that early tool use was more widespread and investment in tool behavior was more complex than previously thought.
